The legal end of a marriage, also called a divorce.
Any person under the age of sixteen (16) years of age.
Also called CSLP. A community service program for persons charged with drug offenses. Upon successful completion of the community service sentence, the criminal case is dismissed.
A person who is not a judge but who is authorized to hear and decide certain types of cases. For example, family support magistrates hear cases involving child support.
term has meaning similar to `alimony' except that award, settlement or agreement arises out of non-marital relationship of parties (i.e., non-marital partners)
A person who assists the judge and oversees cases as they go through the court.

a) Non-surety bond where the defendant's signature alone guarantees the amount of bond and the defendant is not required to post any property or retain the services of a professional bail bondsperson as collateral. b) Promise to appear.
A child or youth who has (a) been abandoned, (b) is being denied proper attention, (c) is being permitted to live under conditions injurious to his/her well being, or (d) has been abused.
A pending lawsuit. Jurisdiction or control that courts have over property in a case waiting for final disposition. A notice of lis pendens is filed on the land records.
A decision or sentence imposed by a judge.
A criminal court order issued by a judge to protect a family or household member.
Formal accusation of a crime.
questioning by a party or his attorney of an adverse party or a witness called by an adverse party
A Special Session of the Superior Court that is responsible for hearing cases involving charges of drug offenses.
A lawsuit or action in a court.
a tract or a plot of land
Money paid to the court while taking an appeal to cover costs and damages to the other party, if the appeal is not successful.
an obligation to do, to eventually do, or to refrain from doing something; money owed; or according to law one's responsibility for his/her conduct; or one's responsibility for causing an injury
to edit, revise
a special finding of the facts of a case by a jury leaving to the court the application of the law to the facts thus found
A hearing for a judge to decide if the defendant’s bond amount needs to be changed.
Vacating a case by the court, usually for failure to prosecute.

1. Geographical place where some legal matter occurs or may be determined. 2. The geographical area within which a court has jurisdiction. It relates only to a place or territory within which either party may require a case to be tried. A defect in venue may be waived by the parties.
the determination of a jury on the facts
Legal mandate authorizing an enforcement officer to remove persons and their personal property from their premises.
Security against loss or damages, exemption from penalty or liability, amount paid as compensation under an indemnity agreement.
is an instruction to deadlocked jurors in civil and criminal cases, urging those jurors who disagree with the majority vote to reexamine the majority views in an effort to reach a unanimous verdict.
A court with limited authority to hear certain kinds of cases, such as adoption, guardianship, mental health commitments. Not a part of the Superior Court system.

A judge who reaches the age of 65, or who meets certain other requirements and chooses senior status. Senior judges hear cases on a part time basis until they reach the mandatory retirement age of 70.
a court order for a party to stop doing or to start doing a specific act
Any location that the defendant, through regular solicitation or advertisement, has held out as its place of business (sec. 308.6 CPLR).

A person who mediates disagreements and negotiates agreements in custody, visitation and divorce cases. At the request of the judge, a family relations counselor may evaluate a family situation by interviewing each parent and the children in the family. The family relations counselor then writes a report for the judge, making recommendations about custody and visitation. Works in the Family Services Office.
to require a person, by writ of injunction from a court of equity, to perform or to abstain or desist from some act
A formal agreement between litigants and/or their attorneys resolving their dispute.
Conference with attorneys to determine scope of possible trial with view toward resolving issues through agreement.
A list of cases in which hearing by the judge or magistrate is requested or required.
One who is legally liable for the debt, default, or failure to carry out a duty of another.

a written or printed document prepared by the lawyers on each side of a dispute and submitted to the court in support of their arguments - a brief includes the points of law which the lawyer wished to establish, the arguments the lawyer uses, and the legal authorities on which the lawyer rests his/her conclusions.
written questions propounded by one party and served on an adversary, who must provide written answers thereto under oath

A state-appointed person who may set the amount of bond for persons detained at a police station prior to arraignment in court, and who recommends to the court the amount of bond that should be set for the defendant on each criminal case.
a plaintiff's response to a defendant's answer when the answer contains a counterclaim
a proceeding to have a case examined by an appropriate higher court to see if a lower court's decision was made correctly according to law
a prescribed number of persons selected according to law and sworn to make findings of fact
a case in which the trial of the liability issue in a personal injury or wrongful death case is heard separate from and prior to trial of the damages in question
directions given by the judge to the jury

sworn testimony of a witness
A person under age 18, the age of legal majority.
in matrimonial law, a cessation of cohabitation of husband and wife by mutual agreement, or in the case of "judicial separation," under the decree of a court
the body of law which originated in England and upon which present day U.S. law is based
A judicial tribunal or a place of jurisdiction. A meeting for discussion.
In a special proceeding, one who commences a formal written application, requesting some action or relief, addressed to a court for determination. Also known as a plaintiff in a civil action
the formal examination of a legal controversy in court so as to determine the issue

a civil judicial proceeding whereby one party prosecutes another for a wrong done or for protection of a right or prevention of a wrong; requires service of process on adversary party or potentially adversary party
"Also known as". Used to list aliases or another name, or another spelling of a name used by a person.
an affidavit intended to certify the service of a writ, notice, or other document
An accused persons answer to a criminal charge. For example

a document attesting that the parties in a lawsuit are ready to go to trial

Also called DIC. A community based program that provides monitoring, supervision and services to people who would otherwise be incarcerated. Day Incarceration Center clients are supervised during the daytime hours, seven days per week.
To be found guilty of committing a crime.
A retired judge who presides over cases referred by the court with agreement of counsel for both parties. Has full powers of an active trial judge.
a penalty or punishment provided as a means of enforcing obedience to a law, rule or code; also, an authorization
an instruction by the judge to the jury to return a specific verdict
A court order that prohibits contact by a defendant with a victim; can be ordered by a judge, a bail commissioner, a probation officer or a parole officer.
a fixed charge for service rendered on behalf of court
A judge, constitutional state referee or any three judges of the Superior Court, appointed by the Chief Court Administrator to conduct an investigation into the commission of a crime or crimes.
a book used for keeping a record of specific documents or events having legal effect
Do it yourself divorce - (en epañol).
In the matter of; concerning.

to attach a portion of the wages or other property of a debtor to secure repayment of the debt
the party being sued or the party accused of committing the offense charged
a document filed with the court placing a cause on the trial calendar
A decision of an Arbitrator.

1. In civil actions, a claim brought by a defendant against the plaintiff for an unlimited amount of money. 2. In small claims/commercial claims, a claim brought by a defendant against the plaintiff for an amount not to exceed the maximum monetary jurisdiction allowed in the small claims/commercial claims court.
Rejecting a potential juror.
The process of deducting money from wages to pay a judgment. Also called a garnishment or attachment.
To atone for an offense, to submit to a court's mandate (i.e., to purge oneself of contempt of court)

A statement of the nature and substance of the cause of action, for money only, which indicates the amount of the claim. It may be set forth upon the summons or attached to it. INFANT An individual who has not attained the age of eighteen (18).

The date on which the 90-day waiting period for a divorce begins. Also, the date that starts the countdown for things taking place in a case, including the deadlines for filing certain papers, including the date by which the defendant should file an appearance. Nothing happens in court on the return date and no one needs to go to court on the return date. The return date is always a Tuesday in civil and family cases. In summary process (eviction) cases, the return date is any week day, Monday through Saturday, except a holiday, usually 7 to 10 days from the date the clerk signs the summons if the summons is signed by the clerk.
In civil cases, the statement of relief desired.
Placement of an adjudicated delinquent under the supervision of a juvenile probation officer.
A specialized court designed to hear complicated family cases. One judge hears the case from start to finish. Located in Middletown.
To carry on a case or judicial proceeding. To proceed against a person criminally.
a legal means, such as a summons, used to subject a defendant in a lawsuit to the jurisdiction of the court; broadly, refers to all writs issued in the course of a legal proceeding
Civil actions to recover damages, or money, up to $5000.The rules of evidence are relaxed and people often represent themselves instead of hiring an attorney.
Geographical Area. The court location where motor vehicle and most criminal cases are heard. There are 22 Geographical Areas in Connecticut.
To assert a fact in a pleading.
A person under probation supervision whose location is unknown, in violation of the conditions of their probation.

Money ordered to be paid by the defendant to the victim to reimburse the victim for the costs of the crime. Generally making good, or giving the equivalent for any loss, damage or injury caused by a persons actions. Often a condition of probation.
for oneself; in one's own behalf; in person; a pro se party is one who, without representation, acts as his/her own attorney

A division within the Judicial Branch. The primary responsibilities of the Office of Adult Probation are to supervise persons placed on probation, to conduct investigations for the court to provide background information on convicted offenders and to conduct eligibility investigations for special programs.
Contains the rules of court and forms which must be followed in all Connecticut court cases. Available in all courthouse law libraries.
The taking of property into legal custody by an enforcement officer (see specialty section
a paper submitted by a defendant in which he/she responds to and/or denies the allegations of the plaintiff
that part of the court which assigns cases for trial (NYS)
Any proceeding or action taken with respect to a specific case after it has been filed with the court.
An attorney appointed and paid by the state who defends a person in a criminal case after the court finds that the person is indigent--financially unable to hire a private attorney.

A plea in a criminal case that allows the defendant to be convicted without admitting guilt for the crime charged. Also called nolo contendre. Although a finding of guilty is entered on the criminal court record, the defendant can deny the charges in a civil action based on the same acts.
Money for alimony and/or child support, which is overdue and unpaid.
the act of lying or stating falsely under oath

A plea in a criminal case in which the defendant does not admit guilt, but agrees that the state has enough evidence against him or her to get a conviction. Allows the defendant to enter into a plea bargain with the state. If the judge accepts the Alford Plea, a guilty finding is made on the record.

lack of legal qualification or fitness (physical, intellectual or moral fitness) to discharge a legally required duty or to handle one's own affairs; also relates to matters not admissible in evidence
When a criminal defendant is brought before a judge after conviction for ordering the terms of the punishment.
A printed list of cases to be presented to the court for hearing.

A unique number the court clerk assigns to a case. It must be used on all future papers filed in the court case. Each docket number starts with two letters that tell the type of case. CI = criminal infraction; CR = criminal case; CV = civil case; FA = family case; MI = motor vehicle infraction; MV= motor vehicle case; SC = small claims.
claim litigated by co-defendants or co-plaintiffs against each other and not against a party on the opposite side of the litigation
memorandum in writing, which is a very brief statement of the reasons for a decision, without detailed explanation
a sum imposed as punishment for an offense
the act of witnessing an instrument in writing at the request of the party making the same, and subscribing it as a witness

an oral or written direction of a court or judge
a legal proceeding that bars or extinguishes right
A crime that carries a maximum penalty of one year and/or a $2,000 fine.
Programs operated by service providers under the Office of Alternative Sanctions used to detain juveniles instead of in a Juvenile Detention Center.
An official transcript of a document from public records, made in a form to be used as evidence and authenticated or certified as a true copy, (e.g. exemplification of a judgment).
a person sworn at a judicial proceeding to translate oral or written language
Trial by a judge, rather than by a jury.

the act of terminating a judicial proceeding
an injury or wrong committed, either with or without force, and either intentionally or negligently, to the person or property of another
A secure facility for juveniles operated by the Division of Juvenile Detention Services of the Connecticut Judicial Branch, open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
Also called a Mitt. The formal document prepared by the court clerk to present a convicted defendant in a criminal case to the Department of Correction for incarceration.
a formal written request to a court, which initiates a special proceeding
A court order to deduct child support or alimony payments from someone’s wages. All child support court orders must include an income withholding order unless both parents ask the judge not to.
The person who refers a defendant to community service work and supervises the defendant’s completion of that work.
An attorney who represents a state agency in civil cases.
If the defendant fails to appear in court as scheduled, the judge may order the bond forfeited (paid to the state) and the defendant rearrested.
technically, a writ summoning persons to court to act as jurors; popularly used as meaning the body of names thus summoned

Also called Superior Court for Juvenile Matters. A special division of the Superior Court designated to hear all cases concerning uncared for, dependent children and youth and delinquents. All juvenile court proceedings and case records are confidential and are not public information.
Also called ADR. Any method used to resolve disputes other than traditional trial proceedings. For example, mediation. ADR programs speed up the disposition of civil cases.
A specialized court designed to hear complicated child protection cases. One judge hears the case from start to finish. Located in Middletown.
one fixing rights of parties without ordering anything to be done
Legal fatherhood.
A legal paper requesting that a person be required to remain within the jurisdiction of the court (either through incarceration or posting of a bond.)
Deposit of a sum of money or filing of a bond in court.
To prevent or stop
a temporary postponement of the proceedings of a case until a specified future time
attorney whose name appears in the permanent records or files of a case
one who swears to an affidavit; deponent
Illegally forcing a tenant out of rented property, usually by changing the locks on the doors.
Also called bail. Money or property given to the court for the temporary release of a defendant, to ensure that the defendant will return to court. There are two kinds of bonds
A joining of two or more actions to be tried together.
Summons compelling a person to appear in court on a specific date to answer to a request that certain orders be modified or vacated.
From the beginning, a new trial.
Questioning by a party or the attorney of an adverse party or a witness.

A defendant’s written application to a three judge panel to review the sentence. Must be filed within 30 days after being sentenced with the court clerk. A review decision can increase or decrease the sentence.

two or more actions involving a common question of law or fact may be joined by court order for trial - the actions are not merged but remain separate and distinct and may result in one or more verdicts and judgments
a statute that declares that no actions of a specified kind be commenced after a specified period of time after the cause of action arose
A person who keeps track of your case and supervises the scheduling of hearings and trials.
one who testifies to what he/she has seen, heard, or otherwise observed
the calling of matters requiring parties, or their attorneys, to appear and be heard, usually done at the beginning of each court day
a decision or order of the court - a final decree is one which fully and finally disposes of the litigation; an interlocutory decree is a provisional or preliminary decree which is not final

A Latin term meaning “friend of the court.” An Amicus Curiae brief is filed by someone who is not a party to a case but has an interest in its outcome. A person who wants to file an amicus curiae brief usually has to get the court’s permission to do so.
the act of going before a qualified officer (e.g., Clerk) and declaring the validity of the document. The officer certifies same, whose certification is known as the acknowledgment
To formally complete a document by acknowledgement or oath.
Subject matter
termination of a proceeding for a procedurally prescribed reason
A legal status, applied to people 16 years of age and older, who have been convicted of a crime and placed under the supervision of a probation officer for a period of time set by the court.
A type of non-financial bond where the defendant agrees to return to court without giving cash or property.
The agreement a defendant makes with the prosecutor to avoid a trial. Usually involves pleading guilty to lesser charges in exchange for a lighter sentence.
A sentence of incarceration equal to the amount of time a defendant has already spent in state custody waiting for disposition of the case.
Criminal punishment that is less restrictive than incarceration.
the failure to diligently assert a right, which results in a refusal to allow relief
the result of a judicial proceeding by withdrawal, settlement, order, judgment or sentence
person whose testimony on some issue has been judicially determined as relevant and substantial

in a pleading, deposition or other paper connected with a case in court, it is the heading or introductory clause which shows the names of the parties, name of the court, number of the case on the docket or calendar, etc.

a type of testimony given by a witness who relates not what he/she knows personally, but what others have told the witness, or what the witness has heard said by others; may be admissible or inadmissible in court depending upon rules of evidence
Date on which the case will next be heard in court.
a preliminary examination where evidence is taken for the purpose of determining an issue of fact and reaching a decision on the basis of that evidence
to separate, set apart, hold aside for safekeeping or awaiting some determination; jurors are sequestered when not permitted to return home until the case is closed
When a convicted offender receives a suspended term of incarceration and is then supervised by a probation officer for a period of time set by a judge.
in trial practice, an address delivered by the court to the jury at the close of the case instructing the jury as to what principles of law they are to apply in reaching a decision

the submission voluntarily or involuntarily of a disputed matter to selected persons and the substitution of their award or decision for the judgment of a court or its confirmation by the court as a judgment of the court
A mandatory program for persons involved in a divorce with children or a custody or visitation case. Must be attended within 60 days of the return date on the summons.
the exhibition or delivery of a writ, notice, etc., officially notifying a person of some action or proceeding in which that person is concerned
a subpoena requiring a person to produce specified documents or records in a trial
Also called AIC. A community based program that provides monitoring, supervision and services to people who would otherwise be incarcerated.
A court order describing the conditions under which two married people will live separately.
an order prepared by counsel for signature of the court (usually based on a memorandum decision)
A meeting scheduled by the court to review the case.
a court room where specified business of a court is to be conducted by a judicial officer

Short for nollo prosequi, which means "no prosecution". A disposition of a criminal or motor vehicle case where the prosecutor agrees to drop the case against the defendant but keeps the right to reopen the case and prosecute at any time during the next thirteen months. The nolle is entered on the court record and the defendant is released from custody. If the defendant stays out of trouble during the thirteen months, the case is removed from the official court records.
right held by one person to use the land of another for a special purpose
in the judge's chamber out of the presence of the jury and the public
Any person sixteen (16) to eighteen (18) years of age.
All property except real property; personal property. For example
an order issued by the court to a person to attend court and give testimony

a swearing to the truth of a statement which, if made by one who knows it to be false, may subject one to a prosecution for perjury or other legal proceedings
a paper, document or other article produced and exhibited to a court during a trial or hearing and, on being accepted, is marked for identification or admitted in evidence
The adjournment or postponement of a court case to another day.
To disqualify oneself as a judge

The legal status of persons who have been arrested for a crime committed when they were between the ages of 16 and 18 and who meet other requirements. All 16- and 17- year-old defendants are treated as youthful offenders, except those who have been charged with certain felonies, have already been convicted of a felony on the adult docket, or have been adjudicated as a serious juvenile offender. For defendants treated as Youthful Offenders, the information and proceedings are confidential and do not become a part of the person’s criminal record.
a reason given in proof or rebuttal
a record of the judgment with the supporting papers
a written opinion or decision of a court on a litigated question, giving the court's conclusion on factual and legal issues (this may constitute the order of the court if so stated)

An electronic system that provides the Probation Officer or Bail Commissioner a report about whether the offender has left home during the time when the offender was required to remain at his or her home.
a questioning of prospective jurors by the attorneys, and, on application of any party, by the judge, to see if any of them should be disqualified or removed by challenge or examination
a civil proceeding or motion for obtaining court approval of the settlement of an infant's claim
Action dismissed on the merits which prevents renewal of the same claim or cause of action.
filing by any person aggrieved by an assessment of a one, two or three family, owner occupied residential structure used for residential purposes (including condominiums) (NYS)
the process by which jurors are selected and sworn to their task
the court's or jury's decision on issues of fact
a proceeding, order, motion, application, request, submission etc., made by or granted for the benefit of one party only; done for, in behalf of, or on application of one party only
Legal process which commands a witness to appear and testify.

Paper instituting the action (e.g., Summons, Motion, Infants's Compromise).
A form used to commence a civil action and acquire jurisdiction over a party
A solemn and formal declaration under penalties of perjury that a statement is true, without an oath.
notes, which are taken by a clerk, of events that occurred in court
A person who supervises child support payments and brings parents to court to enforce child support orders. May also file legal papers to modify or change child support orders.
The release of a youth from the legal authority and control of the youth's parents and the corresponding release of the youth’s parents from their obligations to the youth.
the official record of proceedings in a trial or hearing
general term for remedies or proceedings which are not ordinary actions, e.g., condemnation
A law enacted by a legislative body.
to make void, as to dissolve the bonds of marriage

Also called FWSN. A family that includes a child, who (a) runs away without just cause, (b) is beyond the control of his/her parents/guardian, (c) has engaged in indecent or immoral conduct, and/or (d) is a truant or continuously defiant of school rules and regulations.
A dispute resolution process in which an impartial third party assists the parties to voluntarily reach a mutually acceptable settlement.
Related by blood.
Giving the court clerk legal papers which become part of the case file.
Upheld, agreed with (e.g.,The Appellate Court affirmed the judgment of the City Court).
A surety; one who has put up cash or property as collateral before a defendant may be released.
A complaint filed against an attorney or judge, claiming an ethics violation.
An offense for which the only sentence authorized is a fine.
The most common reason for granting a divorce. It means there is no hope of the husband and wife getting back together again. Also known as "no-fault" divorce.

the geographical, subject matter, and monetary limitations of a court. Personal jurisdiction- Directed to a specific person to impose a personal liability on him (usually the defendant). Subject matter jurisdiction- Topic of consideration, thing in dispute, right claimed by one party against another
to stop, bar, or impede
the security given (or posted) to ensure the future appearance of a defendant
whenever the parties to a suit come to a point in the pleadings which is affirmed on one side and denied on the other, they are said to be "at issue"
the act of freeing a person from the charge of an offense by means of a decision, verdict or other legal process; to discharge
In civil or family cases, failing to pay an amount of money when due
Legal recognition of the ownership of property, usually proven by a document.

Persons in the Division of Juvenile Detention Services who provide safe and secure transportation services for juveniles detained at Juvenile Detention Centers, Alternative Detention Program and Girls’ Detention Program.

the removal of a suit begun in one county or district to another county or district for trial, though the term may also apply to the removal of a suit from one court to another court of the same county or district

Juvenile Court hearing to determine whether a child, 14 or older, charged with a serious juvenile offense should have his/her case transferred to a criminal court and be subject to the same processes and penalties as an adult charged with the same crime.

an action which may be brought for the purpose of restraining the threatened infliction of wrongs or injuries, and the prevention of threatened illegal action; case in which payment of money damages will not be adequate compensation
Member of a jury.
The different parts of a complaint, which could each be a basis or grounds for the lawsuit.
a formal interrogation of parties and witnesses before trial

a trial which has been terminated and declared void prior to the reaching of verdict due to extraordinary circumstance, serious prejudicial misconduct or hung jury - it does not result in a judgment for any party but merely indicates a failure of trial
the party bringing a civil action

A lawsuit other than a criminal case usually filed in a Judicial District courthouse. Includes family actions (divorces, child support, etc) and small claims cases, although these are both separately designated.
An order signed by a judge of the Superior Court authorizing admission of a juvenile to a Juvenile Detention Center, pending a hearing on the next business day.

juridicaljargon.jj: detention hearing or detention release hearing
juridicaljargon.description: A hearing on the first business day after a juvenile is admitted to juvenile detention concerning the legality and appropriateness of continued detention of the juvenile. The detention decision must be reviewed at least every fifteen days.
one who is appointed by a court to manage the affairs of a protected person
1. Prohibit - to bar the prosecution of an action. 2. The members of the legal profession.
Free legal representatives in civil cases for income eligible persons. Call 1-800-453-3320 to apply.
an order prepared by the court

The court requires cash, real estate or a professional bail bondpersons signature as collateral before releasing the defendant back into the community. (The court may allow the defendant to post ten percent of the bond in cash to secure his or her release.)

the power to distribute equitably upon divorce all property legally and beneficially acquired during marriage by husband and wife or either of them, whether legal title lies in their joint or individual names
a jury whose members cannot reconcile their differences of opinion and thus cannot reach a verdict
the assertion, declaration, or statement of a party to an action, made in a pleading, setting out what the party expects to prove
Also called JTO. A person who provides safe transportation services for juveniles in custody.
A person under the age of 16 who commits a criminal act.
A person under the legal majority age of 18 who is granted most rights and legal privileges of an adult (C.G.S.§46b-150, et seq.).
the stamping on a document of the date it is received
the first address of counsel prior to offering of evidence
an agreement by attorneys on opposite sides of a case as to any matter pertaining to the proceedings or trial - most stipulations must be in writing
evidence given by word of mouth; the oral testimony of a witness
A sworn statement containing facts about a child involved in a case, including full name of the child, date of birth, current and past residences and other information as may be required by law.
to close a case file from public scrutiny - in instances of youthful offenders and acquittal, sealing orders are issued by the court to prevent the public from obtaining information on the cases
an order issued by the court requiring a person to produce specified documents or records in a trial
a schedule of matters to be heard in court
the term, as applied to judgment of dismissal, is as conclusive of rights of parties as if action had been prosecuted to final adjudication adverse to the plaintiff

A hearing held before a judge to determine whether or not a person has violated the conditions of probation. If there is a finding that a violation has occurred, the judge may impose all or part of the original sentence.
A program for family violence offenders that if successfully completed, results in the dismissal of criminal charges.
reimbursement for actual loss or injury, as distinguished from exemplary or punitive damages
To hold in suspense an action that cannot reasonably be tried because a party or witness is in the military service.
a special master is an attorney appointed on an ad hoc basis to assist the court in hearing motions (NYS)
A Friend of the Court. A non-party to a proceeding that the Court permits to present its views.

A person who has the power and duty to take care of another person and/or to manage the property and rights of another person who is considered incapable of taking care of his or her personal affairs.
A formal request by one party in a lawsuit to disclose information or facts known by other parties or witnesses.
Written notice of a petitioner that a hearing will be held in a court to determine the relief requested in an annexed petition.
a practice whereby the jurors are asked individually whether they assented, and still assent, to the verdict
Any criminal offense for which a person may be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of more than of one year.
A community based program for drug offenders that provides education about the harmful effects of drug abuse and also supervises community service.
A claim asserted by a defendant, styled a third-party plaintiff, against a person, styled a third-party defendant.
An order directed to a private corporation, or any of its officers, or to an executive, administrative or judicial officer, or to a lower court, commanding the performance of a particular act.
Liquidated damages pursuant to contract, promissory note, law, etc.
a dismissal "without prejudice" allows a new suit to be brought on the same cause of action

the power to take private property for public use by condemnation, i.e., the legal process by which real estate of a private owner is taken for public use without the owner's consent, but upon the award and payment of just compensation
A prison sentence that is suspended in whole or in part provided certain conditions of probation or conditional discharge are met by the defendant.
a legally enforceable agreement between two or more persons or parties (oral or written)
A person who provides pretrial mediation of landlord/tenant cases to reach settlement. Also provides information about community resources to litigants.
A legal case filed against someone who is a holdover tenant (someone who remains after the expiration of a lease).
Eighteen (18) years of age. See CPLR Section 1206.
Discharge of a legal obligation, as in a "Satisfaction of Judgment."
Regarding the right or title to property.
Party to a legal action

legal process by which an appellate court transmits to the court below the proceedings before it, together with its decision, for such further action and entry of judgment as is required by the decision of the appellate court

the party who initiates the motion

Person having a direct interest in a legal matter, transaction or proceeding.
complaint or petition, answer, and reply

Confinement to a state correctional institute or prison.

a system, established for all civil actions and proceedings heard in Supreme and County Court, which provides for the continuous supervision of each action and proceeding by a single judge (NYS)

Money a court requires one spouse to pay the other spouse for support before and/or after the divorce is granted. If you do not ask for alimony at the final hearing, you can never get it in the future.

"You have the body." - the name given a variety of writs whose object is to bring a person before a court or judge - in most common usage, it is directed to the official or person detaining another, commanding him/her to produce the body of a person detained so the court may determine if such person has been denied his/her liberty without due process of law
An eviction case.
that place where a person has a true and permanent home - a person may have several residences, but only one domicile

the authorized act of physically destroying information, in files, computers or other depositories
To pay the court ordered bond amount with cash or property.
Legally forcing a tenant out of rented property. (Housing Publications)

the special referee has the authority to exercise judicial functions when assigned duties by the court to determine the following (1) to determine an issue (binding) (2) to perform an act (disclosure) (3) to hear and report - matrimonial actions may be included (NYS)
Juvenile court proceeding to determine whether the allegations made in a petition are true and whether the child/youth should be subject to orders of the court.

An order issued by a judge of the Superior Court finding that there is probable cause that a juvenile committed an offense or a violation of a court order and ordering that the juvenile be held in a Juvenile Detention Center or some alternative facility until further order of the court.
a number issued by the county clerk, which is used to identify a case - in civil matters there is usually a charge
A program of outpatient group therapy for alcohol abusers.
A Court Clerk's Journal of Courtroom proceedings.
upon its own motion, initiation or will; without a prior request
The person who maintains the official court record of your case. The court clerks’ office receives all court papers and assigns hearing dates.
A person who works with domestic violence victims to determine their needs and inform them of their rights and resources available to them.
A civil court order to protect a family or household member from physical abuse.
to strengthen; to add weight by additional evidence
to set aside a previous action
a person or institution who manages money or property for another, and who must exercise a standard of care in such management activity imposed by law or contract

a thing judicially acted upon or decided
the succession of events constituting the process by which judicial action is invoked and utilized pursuant to procedure

the determination reached by a court in any judicial proceeding, which is the basis of the judgment
Action or inaction that disobeys a condition of probation.

Copy of a document signed and certified as a true copy of an original by the Clerk of the Court or other authorized persons (e.g., lawyer).
Money paid by a parent to help meet the financial needs of a child.

Programs that provide extensive drug or alcohol treatment on an inpatient basis.

a claim upon the property of another as security for some debt

Lawyer or attorney.

a "default" in an action of law occurs when a defendant omits to plead or otherwise defend within the time allowed, or fails to appear at the trial
The pleadings, the exhibits and the transcript made by the court reporter of all proceedings in a trial.
